title: How to Make Gutti Vankaya

steps.headline: Make the paste.
steps.description:
In a blender, coarsely blend onions, tamarind, garam masala powder, chili powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, and ginger-garlic paste. Remove the paste from the blender and set aside. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/39\/Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/3\/39\/Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/aid1048688-v4-728px-Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Cut the eggplants into quarters.
steps.description: One cut lengthwise, one cut width wise. If they are small enough, you can just cut them in half.

steps.headline: Mix the paste well with all of the eggplant pieces.
steps.description: Don't expect to use all of the paste, there should be some left over.

steps.headline: Over high heat, fry the remaining paste for 10-15 minutes.
Add the turmeric powder and stir.
Add the stuffed eggplants.
steps.description: Spoon some of the mixture over them, until they are well coated.

steps.headline: Add a bit of water.
steps.description: The curry should not be liquid, it should be semi-dry.

steps.headline: Cover and simmer.
steps.description:
It takes about 15 minutes depending on the size of the eggplant pieces. Check the tenderness by pricking them with a fork. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/69\/Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-9Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/6\/69\/Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-9Bullet1.jpg\/aid1048688-v4-728px-Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Sprinkle with sesame seeds or poppy seeds just before serving.
The gutti vankaya is ready to serve!

text:
Make the paste. In a blender, coarsely blend onions, tamarind, garam masala powder, chili powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, and ginger-garlic paste. Remove the paste from the blender and set aside. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/3/39/Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/aid1048688-v4-728px-Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut the eggplants into quarters. One cut lengthwise, one cut width wise. If they are small enough, you can just cut them in half. Mix the paste well with all of the eggplant pieces. Don't expect to use all of the paste, there should be some left over. Over high heat, fry the remaining paste for 10-15 minutes. Add salt to taste. Add the turmeric powder and stir. Add the stuffed eggplants. Spoon some of the mixture over them, until they are well coated. Add a bit of water. The curry should not be liquid, it should be semi-dry. Cover and simmer. It takes about 15 minutes depending on the size of the eggplant pieces. Check the tenderness by pricking them with a fork. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-9Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"/images/thumb/6/69/Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-9Bullet1.jpg/aid1048688-v4-728px-Make-Gutti-Vankaya-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"485","licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Sprinkle with sesame seeds or poppy seeds just before serving. The gutti vankaya is ready to serve!
